ticket.title: render does not take symbol as template argument
ticket.original-body:
render :template => 'index' Works
render :template => :index does not and gives this error:
private method `sub!' called for :index:Symbol (NoMethodError)
Should not the template key value be coerced to a string inside the render method? Symbols and strings are interchangeable elsewhere in Rails.

render :template => :index does not and gives this error:

Should not the template key value be coerced to a string inside the render method? Symbols and strings are interchangeable elsewhere in Rails.

Should not the template key value be coerced to a string inside the render method? Symbols and strings are interchangeable elsewhere in Rails.

version.title: render does not take symbol as template argument

version.body: template option expect controller/action. I think you want to do render :action => :index or just render :index.
version.body-html:
template option expect controller/action.
I think you want to do render :action => :index or just render :index.
version.title: render does not take symbol as template argument

version.body: I think that that appraisal rather misses the point. The issue is one of 'least surprise'. Is there a strong technical reason why symbols should not be allowed as targets to the :template key in the render hash? If not, then why are not symbols permitted to substitute for strings as they generally are elsewhere? Why the exception in this particular case?
version.body-html: I think that that appraisal rather misses the point. The issue is one of 'least surprise'. Is there a strong technical reason why symbols should not be allowed as targets to the :template key in the render hash? If not, then why are not symbols permitted to substitute for strings as they generally are elsewhere? Why the exception in this particular case?
version.title: render does not take symbol as template argument

version.body: If render :template => "index" works, that is the bug. We don't expect it to. render :template accepts a path to the view, like "posts/index". render :template => "index" should just work if you have a file at app/views/index.html.erb.
version.body-html: If render :template => "index" works, that is the bug. We don't expect it to. render :template accepts a path to the view, like "posts/index". render :template => "index" should just work if you have a file at app/views/index.html.erb.
version.title: render does not take symbol as template argument
render does not take symbol as template argument

version.body: Then is there a case for the render method to return a specific ArgumentError message in the event it receives a symbol rather than a string as the value for the :template key? I follow that the present error implies that a Sting is expected but given the frequent interchangeability of strings with symbols within Rails perhaps an ArguemntError containing the explicit statement that the :template parameter requires a String argument would be useful.
version.body-html: Then is there a case for the render method to return a specific ArgumentError message in the event it receives a symbol rather than a string as the value for the :template key? I follow that the present error implies that a Sting is expected but given the frequent interchangeability of strings with symbols within Rails perhaps an ArguemntError containing the explicit statement that the :template parameter requires a String argument would be useful.
version.title: render does not take symbol as template argument

version.body:
render template => 'index' works because the following method converts options from
@@@ ruby {:template => 'index'} @@@
to
@@@ ruby {:template=>"index", :tempalte=>"index", :prefix=>"users"} @@@
@@@ ruby #abstract_controller/rendering.rb def _normalize_options(options) if options[:partial] == true options[:partial] = action_name end
if (options.keys & [:partial, :file, :template, :once]).empty? options[:prefix] ||= _prefix end
options[:template] ||= (options[:action] || action_name).to_s options end @@@
version.body-html:
render template => 'index' works because the following method converts options from

{:template => 'index'}

to

{:template=>"index", :tempalte=>"index", :prefix=>"users"}

#abstract_controller/rendering.rb
def _normalize_options(options)
  if options[:partial] == true
    options[:partial] = action_name
  end

  if (options.keys & [:partial, :file, :template, :once]).empty?
    options[:prefix] ||= _prefix
  end

  options[:template] ||= (options[:action] || action_name).to_s
  options
end
version.title: render does not take symbol as template argument

version.body:
Never mind. I had a typo.
as @JV said it expects /index.
